title: Botticelli in the Fire, Hampstead Theatre, review: enough nudity to furnish an episode of Game of Thrones
text:
Renaissance Florence in the 1480s and 1490s under the rule of the Medicis was a strange combination of decadence and piety. Relations between the Medicis and the Papacy may have fluctuated but the family was a major force in Italian finance and, as a measure of strategic amity, Florentine artists were commissioned to adorn the new Sistine Chapel.

It was a period of intrigue, artistic vitality and religious fervour. Putting a spoke in the gilded wheel of the Medici machine was one Girolamo Savonarola, a Dominican friar who preached against the fleshy sacrilege and secularisation of art, carnal appetites and the corruption of the church. Initially residing in the city with the blessing of Lorenzo...
